ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about some of the current debates about intersectionality in the field.
I gained insight into the field of WGSS and developed my skills in having fruitful conversations with an interdisciplinary group of my peers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated the space of the course -- meeting folks from other disciplines over wine/dinner and discussing interesting reading together. However, I wish the course topic was a bit more varied in scope.

The choice of readings was excellent -- I loved how the authors spoke to each other and the books intertwined. I am glad that we dove into a particular question (the state of intersectionality) and explored it from various perspectives. I was expecting that the class would be more "the four books every WGSS Certificate holder must have read at least once," or "the four most important books in WGSS published in the past five years;" neither of which was the case. Perhaps the full class version of this workshop could be organized around those lines.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, being in a classroom with other students from across various disciplines who are all invested in WGSS is an opportunity that should not be missed!
